instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PP20V_USBC: What is PP20V_USBC? 20 volt power rail that comes directly from the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.SYS_DETECT_L: What is SYS_DETECT_L? For detection of the battery.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v3 short 5v on chrager ppbus 0v
threads.message:
i was just replace the screen, after connect everything it was work, the i was close all the screen screws and the boom 5v on charger!

what could happened????

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v3 short 5v on chrager ppbus 0v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is main power rail for T2 machines.
You cannot get any other voltage, if no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> present.

Do you get voltage at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v3 short 5v on chrager ppbus 0v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_3GH</SIGNAL> 0v stable
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_3GH_CHGR</SIGNAL> 5.3v -0v every 10s pulsing
<SIGNAL>CHGR_CSI_R_P</SIGNAL> 5.3v -0v every 10s pulsing
<SIGNAL>CHGR_R_N</SIGNAL> 5.3v -0v every 10s pulsing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v3 short 5v on chrager ppbus 0v
threads.message:
From other post with the same problem:
"Let me be more specific; looks like you didn't understand me.
Poste exact (two decimals) voltage for <SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN_R</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL>.
We need to see which side of output resistors is pulled down.
If all are 0.0V, or <SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN_R</SIGNAL> is the lowest, then change <CHIP>U6940</CHIP>"

You didn't read entire thread.
I did the same mistake at the beginning, comparing the signal with <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.
Note that NO "_L" in these names now; ALL must be 0V.

Also can be an input MOSFET from that side.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v3 short 5v on chrager ppbus 0v
threads.message: Each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip has a dual MOSFET associated.
